This information has changed with Java 1.6.  Now one can use a * and a
dire=
ctory of jars.

From - http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/tools/wi=
ndows/classpath.html

Understanding class path wildcards
- Class path entri=
es can contain the basename wildcard character *,
which is considered equiv=
alent to specifying a list of all the files
in the directory with the exten=
sion .jar or .JAR. For example, the
class path entry foo/* specifies all JA=
R files in the directory named
foo. A classpath entry consisting simply of =
* expands to a list of all
the jar files in the current directory.

So a ja=
r folder name is available in 1.6 when the * is used.

But this is new in 1=
.6 so a common oversight.

On Tue, Aug 18, 2009 at 5:11 PM, Vitaliy Berdins=
kikh<skipper13@...> wrote:
> =F7 Tue, 18 Aug 2009 21:35:28 -0000
> "Jef=
f Sexton" <elgintime@...> =D0=C9=DB=C5=D4:
>
>> This is a common ques=
tion, but just the same I can't see the trouble.
>>
>> On Windows with juni=
t 4.1, I create a .bat file like so:
>>
>> set JARS=3D.\bin
>> set JARS=3D%=
JARS%;..\somedir\lib\junit.jar
> not ".\bin" but ".\bin\somejar1.jar;.\bin\=
somejar2.jar..."
>
> classpath contains class folder name and jar names. No=
t jar folder name.
>
